skill.name: uniprot-database
skill.description: Direct REST API access to UniProt. Protein searches, FASTA retrieval, ID mapping, Swiss-Prot/TrEMBL. For Python workflows with multiple databases, prefer bioservices (unified interface to 40+ services). Use this for direct HTTP/REST work or UniProt-specific control.
skill.summary: Direct REST API access to UniProt. Protein searches, FASTA retrieval, ID mapping, Swiss-Prot/TrEMBL....
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: Legitimate bioinformatics tool providing access to the authoritative UniProt protein database. Makes HTTP requests only to the official rest.uniprot.org domain. No credential access, no file system modification beyond expected output, and behavior matches stated purpose.

content.value_statement: Need to find protein sequences and annotations from UniProt? Query protein databases by name, gene, accession, or organism. Retrieve sequences, map identifiers, and access functional annotations via REST API.
actual_capabilities: Search UniProt database by protein name, gene, accession, or organism using query syntax
Retrieve protein sequences in FASTA, JSON, TSV, XML, or other formats
Map protein identifiers between UniProt and external databases like PDB, Ensembl, RefSeq
Access Swiss-Prot reviewed entries or TrEMBL unreviewed entries
Stream large result sets for batch downloads without pagination limits
Retrieve specific fields only to optimize bandwidth and response time
limitations: Maximum 100,000 IDs per ID mapping job
ID mapping results stored for 7 days only
No local caching provided by the skill; implement caching externally for repeated queries
Rate limits apply to the UniProt REST API; implement delays for large batch operations

use_cases.title: Research protein function
use_cases.description: Find protein sequences, functional annotations, GO terms, and cross-references for gene analysis projects.

use_cases.title: Batch retrieve sequences
use_cases.description: Download large protein datasets in FASTA format for phylogenetics, structure prediction, or comparative analysis.

use_cases.title: Map protein identifiers
use_cases.description: Convert protein identifiers between UniProt, PDB, and other databases to integrate data sources.

prompt_templates.title: Basic protein search
prompt_templates.prompt: Search UniProt for insulin proteins in humans using the query: 'insulin AND organism_name:"Homo sapiens"' and return the results in JSON format.

prompt_templates.title: Retrieve sequence
prompt_templates.prompt: Retrieve the protein sequence for UniProt accession P01308 in FASTA format.

prompt_templates.title: Map identifiers
prompt_templates.prompt: Map the UniProt accessions P01308 and P04637 to their corresponding PDB IDs using the ID mapping service.

prompt_templates.title: Advanced search
prompt_templates.scenario: Find reviewed human kinases with structure
prompt_templates.prompt: Search UniProt for reviewed human kinases that have PDB structures. Use the query: 'protein_name:kinase AND organism_id:9606 AND reviewed:true AND xref:pdb'. Return accession, gene names, and PDB cross-references in JSON format.
prompt_templates.description: Search for reviewed human kinases that have PDB structures. Use query: 'protein_name:kinase AND organism_id:9606 AND reviewed:true AND xref:pdb'. Return accession, gene name, and PDB cross-references.

output_examples.input: Search for human hemoglobin proteins with reviewed status
output: â€¢ P68871 - HBB (Hemoglobin subunit beta) - Length: 147 aa
â€¢ P69905 - HBA1 (Hemoglobin subunit alpha 1) - Length: 142 aa
â€¢ P69902 - HBA2 (Hemoglobin subunit alpha 2) - Length: 142 aa

best_practices: Use reviewed:true in queries to get high-quality Swiss-Prot entries for reliable annotations
Request only necessary fields using the fields parameter to reduce bandwidth and improve response time
Implement proper error handling with response.raise_for_status() to catch API failures early
anti_patterns: Do not make unlimited API calls without rate limiting; UniProt enforces usage policies
Do not assume all TrEMBL entries have experimental validation; they are computational predictions
Do not ignore failed IDs in ID mapping results; check the failedIds field for incomplete mappings

faq.question: Which UniProt entry types should I use?
faq.answer: Swiss-Prot entries are manually reviewed and reliable. TrEMBL entries are computationally predicted. Use reviewed:true for quality.

faq.question: What formats are supported?
faq.answer: JSON, TSV, Excel, XML, FASTA, RDF, TXT. Choose based on your workflow: FASTA for sequences, TSV for tables, JSON for parsing.

faq.question: How many proteins can I retrieve at once?
faq.answer: Search endpoint returns up to 500 results per request. Use pagination or the stream endpoint for large datasets without limits.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: This skill only reads public UniProt data. No user data is stored or transmitted to third parties beyond the official UniProt API.

faq.question: Why did my query fail?
faq.answer: Check your query syntax, ensure accession formats are correct, and verify you are not exceeding rate limits. Try smaller batches.

faq.question: How does this compare to bioservices?
faq.answer: This skill provides direct UniProt REST API access. Use bioservices for unified access to 40+ bioinformatics databases in Python.
